body.p: We read with interest the American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition (A.S.P.E.N.) Clinical Guidelines on nutrition support of neonatal patients at risk for necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) published by Dr Fallon and colleagues.1 Although the authors acknowledge that the proposed regimen of advancing enteral feeds by 30 mL/kg/d is based on weak evidence, this approach necessitates some further commenting.

When discussing key issues such as enteral nutrition regimens and the rate of feeding advancement in this very vulnerable patient cohort, it is important to realize what long-term implications NEC will have on these individuals—most important, a disproportionate increase in poor neurological outcome.2 Although slow feeding advancement has been linked to prolonged parenteral nutrition, gut atrophy, nosocomial infection, and delayed hospital discharge,3 in our opinion, the detrimental consequences of NEC clearly outweigh these potential risks.

Moreover, and of importance, infants who are growth restricted in utero are considered to have a higher risk of developing NEC, especially if there has been antenatal detection of absent or reversed end-diastolic flow velocities in Doppler studies of the fetal aorta or umbilical artery. Paradoxically and of importance, most trials of enteral feeding regimens have specifically excluded infants with evidence of intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) from participating because of the perceived high risk of developing NEC.3

Finally, we would like to report on our single-center experience with slow advancements of enteral feeds in very low-birth-weight (VLBW) and extremely low-birth-weight infants, including IUGR babies. It is our standard neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) policy to start enteral/trophic feeds after passage of meconium in these infants. When well tolerated (no abdominal distension, no bilious aspirates, cardiocirculatory stability, no signs of infection, etc), enteral feeds are then increased by 10–15 mL/kg/d. With this regimen, the rate of NEC (as defined by Bell’s criteria) in our NICU with an approximate annual admission of VLBW infants around 50–60 is below 1%, which is well under the reported prevalence of 7% as reported by large neonatal networks from the United States.4 It is important to note that the increase of enteral feeds as practiced in our hospital is even below the average amount usually given in the conservative arm (slow advancement <24 mL/kg/d).

In summary, and contrary to what is suggested by Fallon et al,1 we would argue in favor of slow feeding advancement regimens given the fact that NEC is a detrimental and possibly life-turning event. This position is substantiated by the fact that recent trials had to be prematurely stopped because of a disproportionate rate of NEC in the interventional/fast advancing group.5
